column1: West Timor (Indonesian: Timor Barat) is an area covering the western part of Timor island
column2: except for the district of Oecussi-Ambeno (an East Timorese exclave). Administratively
column3: West Timor is part of East Nusa Tenggara Province
column4: Indonesia. The capital as well as its main port is Kupang. During the colonial period
column5: the area was named Dutch Timor and was a centre of Dutch loyalists during the Indonesian National Revolution (1945–1949). From 1949 to 1975 it was named Indonesian Timor.The total area of West Timor is 16
column7: 279.87 sq mi). The highest peaks are Mount Mutis

column4: as well as several other languages
column7: are also used in East Timor. The other three languages which are only used in the local area of the Austronesian language group from the Fabron branches are Ndao

column1: West Timor was a refugee shelter from 1998 to 2002
column2: due to the prolonged East Timor conflict. Some of the most populous cities are Kupang City with over 400

column1: == History ==
European colonization of Timor began in the 16th century. Although the Portuguese claimed the island of Timor in 1520
column2: the Dutch (in the form of the Dutch East India Company) settled West Timor in 1640
column3: forcing the Portuguese out to East Timor. The subsequent collapse of the company meant that in 1799
column4: the area returned to official Dutch rule. Finally
column6: the border between East and West Timor was finalized by a treaty between Portugal and the Netherlands that was originally signed in 1859 and modified in 1893.

column1: West Timor had the status of residentie within the Dutch East Indies.
Japan conquered the island during World War II in early 1942. Upon Indonesian independence
column2: West Timor became part of the new Republic of Indonesia.

column1: On 6 September 2000
column3: Carlos Caceres-Collazio from Puerto Rico and Samson Aregahegn from Ethiopia – all UNHCR staff members – were killed in an attack by 5
column6: on the office of UNHCR in the town of Atambua
column7: which is in the vicinity of the border with East Timor and where the main refugee camp was located (see attacks on humanitarian workers).

column1: == Geography ==

West Timor is a non-political region that comprises the western half of Timor island with the exception of Oecusse district (which is politically part of East Timor) and forms a part of the Indonesian province of East Nusa Tenggara. The land area of West Timor is 16
column3: 279.87 sq mi). The highest point of West Timor is Mount Mutis

column1: West Timor has large and wide-ranging savannas
column2: and has fairly dry air temperatures

column1: Rote Island
West Timor's largest town and chief port is Kupang
column2: the capital of Nusa Tenggara Timur province.

column1: West Timor lies between Australia and East Timor which makes the island a strategic place for Indonesian trade.
== Administration ==

West Timor is part of the East Nusa Tenggara province. It was formerly split into the City of Kupang (a kabupaten or regency-level administrative area) and four regencies (kabupaten); from west to east these are: Kupang
column3: Timor Tengah Utara (North Central Timor) and Belu. However
column4: a fifth regency – Malaka – was in 2012 formed from the southern half of Belu Regency. Note the administrative area has shrunk as Rote Ndao Regency (Rote and Ndoa islands to the southwest) and Sabu Raijua Regency (the Savu Islands further west) were split off in 2002 and 2009 respectively from Kupang Regency.  The island accounts for 35.5% of the provincial population.

column1: == Population ==
There were approximately 1.98 million inhabitants in 2019
column2: some of them refugees who had fled the 1999 violence in East Timor.

column1: === Languages ===
In addition to the national language
column3: native languages belonging to the Fabronic Stock of the Austronesian group of languages are spoken in West Timor
column4: the others in East Timor. These languages include Uab Meto
column7: Rotinese and Helong.Knowledge of Dutch (the colonial language) is now limited to the older generations.

column1: === Religion ===
In West Timor
column2: Christianity is the religion of just over 97% of the population. Islam is followed by 2.9%. The remaining 0.088% includes Hindus and Buddhists. From the Catholic missionary Apostolic Vicariate of Dutch Timor stem the Metropolitan Archdiocese of Kupang and its suffragan Diocese of Atambua.

column1: == Economy ==
West Timor has an average unemployment rate of 2.39%. 30% of the population lived below the poverty line in 1998; as of 2012
column2: it remained at 30%. The economy is mainly agricultural
column3: using slash-and-burn methods to produce corn
column6: copra and fruit. Some timber harvesting is undertaken
